questions.text: According to Vaughan - Williams - Singh classification of anti-arrhythmic, Identify the segment of action potential most affected by Ibutilide from the following illustration (Marked in roman letters I, II, III and IV)
questions.solution:
Ibutilide

This is another new class III antiarrhythmic that blocks rapid inward rectifier K+ current (Ikr) used i.v. for pharmacological conversion of AFl and AF to sinus rhythm. Efficacy is higher in recent onset cases and in AFl compared to AF.

Induction of Torsades de pointes is a risk.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 579

questions.text: Calcium sensitizer agent indicated in management of decompensated congested cardiac failure is.
questions.solution:
Levosimendan

This inotropic drug acts by sensitizing myocardial troponin C to Ca2+, as well as by inhibiting PDE3. As such, the inotropic effect occurs even in patients receiving b blockers, and is not associated with a change in cytosolic Ca2+ concentration.

It also opens ATP-sensitive K+ channels in vascular smooth muscle cells to cause vasodilatation. Thus, it is another ‘inodilator’, Haemodynamic improvement in heart failure is both due to increase in cardiac contractility as well as reduction in preload and afterload.

Levosimendan infused i.v. is primarily indicated for short-term treatment of acutely decompensated severe chronic heart failure.

The most common side effect is hypotension which may last for few days due to its active metabolite that has long t½.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 568

questions.text: Which of the following agents causes vasodilation by acting as a nitric oxide donor in vascular smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Sodium nitroprusside

It is a rapidly (within seconds) and consistently acting vasodilator with brief duration of action (2-5 min) so that vascular tone can be titrated with the rate of i.v. infusion. Nitroprusside relaxes both resistance and capacitance vessels: reduces t.p.r. as well as c.o. (by decreasing venous return).

Side effects mainly due to vasodilatation are - palpitation, nervousness, vomiting, perspiration, pain in abdomen, weakness, disorientation, and lactic acidosis (caused by the released cyanide).

Nitroprusside has also been used to produce controlled hypotension, in refractory CHF and in acute mitral regurgitation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 613-614

questions.text: A patient with a long history of cardio vascular disease develops worsening Ventricular arrhythmias. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be the cause of the arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
Quinidine is associated with QT interval prolongation and torsade de point arrhythmias. Propranolol can cause heart block. Dobutamine rarely causes ventricular arrhythmias.

The important drug interactions of quinidine are:

  • Rise in blood levels and toxicity of digoxin due to displacement from tissue binding and inhibition of P-glycoprotein mediated renal and biliary clearance of digoxin.
  • Exaggerated fall in BP in patients receiving vasodilators.
  • Risk of torsades de pointes is increased by hypokalaemia caused by diuretics.
  • Synergistic cardiac depression with β-blockers, verapamil, K+ salts.
  • Quinidine inhibits CYP2D6: prolongs t½ of propafenone and inhibits conversion of codeine to morphine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 574

questions.text: A 76-year-old man has suffered from atrial fibrillation for many years. This condition has been under good control with amiodarone and diltiazem until recently, when he started experiencing palpitations and came back to see you. You decide to start the patient on digoxin therapy. How does this medication work?
questions.solution:
Digoxin, a cardiac glycoside, increases vagal activity, resulting in inhibition of the sinoatrial (SA) node and delayed conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node. It also decreases sympathetic tone. Cardiac glycosides increase intracellular sodium while decreasing intracellular potassium; increase intracellular calcium; and increase stroke volume and therefore cardiac output. Cardiac glycosides enhance elimination of sodium and water.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 557

questions.text: Which one of the following is characteristic of nifedipine treatment in patients with essential hypertension?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is a prototype L-type calcium channel blocker and lowers blood pressure by reducing calcium influx into vascular smooth muscle. It has no effect on angiotensin - converting enzyme. Calcium efflux from skeletal muscle cells does not involve the L - type Ca channel. The plasma renin level may increase as a result of the compensatory response to reduced blood pressure. Calcium channel blockers have negligible effects on urine calcium.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 595

questions.text: Comparison of prazosin with atenolol shows that
questions.solution:
Atenolol, but not prazosin, may decrease heart rate. Prazosin-but not atenolol-may increase cardiac output, a compensatory effect. Prazosin may increase renin output (a compensatory response), but β blockers inhibit its release by the kidney. By reducing blood pressure, both may increase central sympathetic outflow (a compensatory response).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 610

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of severe chest pain when he walks uphill to his home in cold weather. The pain disappears when herests. After evaluation and discussion of treatment options, a decisionis made to treat him with nitroglycerin. In advising the patient about the adverse effects he may notice, you point out that nitroglycerin in moderate doses often produces certain symptoms. Which of the following effects might occur due to the mechanism listed?
questions.solution:
The nitrates relax many types of smooth muscle, but the effect on motility in the colon is in significant. Nitroglycerin causes hypotension as a result of arterial and venous dilation. Dilation of arteries in the meninges has no effect on central nervous system function but does cause headache.

Adverse effects of GTNs

These are mostly due to vasodilatation.

  • Fullness in head, throbbing headache; some degree of tolerance develops on continued use.
  • Flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting; these are due to postural hypotension, and are mitigated by lying down. Standing still and alcohol accentuate these symptoms.
  • Methemoglobinemia is not noticeable with clinically used doses; but can further reduce O2 carrying capacity of blood in severe anaemia. Rashes are rare

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 587-588

questions.text: When nitrates are used in combination with other drugs forthe treatment of angina, which one of the following combinations results in additive effects on the variable specified?
questions.solution:
The effects of β blockers (or calcium channel blockers) and nitrates on heart size, force, venous tone, and heart rate are opposite. The effects of β blockers and calcium channel blockers on the variables specified here are the same.

questions.text: Prostaglandin analogue used for pulmonary hypertension is:
questions.solution:
Uses of Epoprostenol

  1. To avoid platelet damage PGI2 (Epoprostenol) can be used to prevent platelet aggregation and damage during haemodialysis or cardiopulmonary bypass. It also improves harvest of platelets for transfusion.
  2. Pulmonary hypertension - PGI2 lowers pulmonary artery resistance. Accordingly, few cases of primary pulmonary hypertension have been successfully maintained on epoprostenol infused continuously in a large vein.
  3. Peripheral vascular diseases PGI2 (or PGE1) infused i.v. can relieve rest pain and promote healing of ischaemic ulcers in severe cases of intermittent claudication and in Raynaud’s disease.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 207

questions.text: A patient on PDE5 inhibitor therapy reports that the last dose was taken around 24hours ago. You are planning to start nitrate therapy in this patient for angina. Which of the following PDE5 inhibitor intake most likely requires a postponement of nitrate therapy to avoid drug interaction?
questions.solution:
The drug interaction between nitrates and PDE5 inhibitor exists for around 24hours. But tadalafil being a long-acting agent, the drug interaction exists beyond 24hours (up to 36 hours). If the above patient had taken tadalafil, the postponement of nitrate therapy and alternative anti-anginal medications can be considered. The combination of nitrates and PDE5 inhibitor has a synergisitic action on intracellular cGMP levels that can result in uninhibited vasodilation and a precipitous fall in blood pressure.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 328

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department with severe chest pain. ECG reveals ventricular tachycardia with occasional normal sinus beats, and ST-segment changes suggestive of ischemia. A diagnosis of myocardial infarction is made, and the man is admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit. His arrhythmia should be treated immediately with
questions.solution:
Lidocaine has limited applications as an antiarrhythmic drug, but emergency treatment of myocardial infarction arrhythmias is one of the most important. Lidocaine is also useful in digoxin-induced arrhythmias. After recovery from the acute phase of a myocardial infarction, β blockers are used for 2yr or more to prevent sudden death arrhythmias.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 575

questions.text:
A drug was tested in the electrophysiology laboratory to determine its effects on the cardiac action potential in normal ventricular cells. The results are shown in the diagram.

Which of the following agent does this drug most resemble?
questions.solution:
The drug effect shown in the diagram includes slowing of the upstroke of the AP but no significant change in repolarization or AP duration. This is most typical of group 1C drugs.

Flecainide

It is the prototype class IC antiarrhythmic which markedly delays Na+ channel recovery. In contrast to propafenone, flecainide has no consistent effect on APD and no β adrenergic blocking property.

It suppresses VES, VT, WPW tachycardia and prevents recurrences of AF and PSVT.

It is reserved for resistant cases of paroxysmal AF and for life-threatening sustained VT in patients not having associated CHF.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 576

choices.text: It has a high affinity for angiotensin IIreceptors
It promotes increased peripheral vascular resistance
It decreases cardiac output and increases after load
It causes venodilation and induces natriuresis

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is diagnosed with congestive heart failure (CHF). You prescribe captopril, a medication proven to reduce hermortality. This agent delivers several benefits to patients with CHF. Which of the following effects is caused by this drug?
questions.solution:
Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cause venodilation and induce natriuresis, thereby reducing preload. A high affinity for angiotensin II receptors represents the mechanism of action of angiotensin-receptor blockers. ACE inhibitors counteract increased peripheral resistance, increase cardiac output, and decrease afterload.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 531
